TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi sealed ClientTargetCollection extends System.Configuration.ConfigurationElementCollection

Docs.summary: Represents a collection of objects. This class cannot be inherited.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The ClientTargetCollection type allows access to the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget> elements of the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetSection> section element collection.
It belongs to a group that includes <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget> and <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetSection>.
## Examples The following code example shows how to obtain the ClientTargetCollection object from the configuration file of an existing Web application.
[!code-vb[System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget#1](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/t-system.web.configurati_80_1.vb)] [!code-cs[System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget#1](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/t-system.web.configurati_80_1.cs)]
The following example shows an excerpt from the configuration file.
``` <clientTarget> <add alias= "uplevel" userAgent="Mozilla/5.0 (compatible;MSIE 6.0;Windows NT 5.1)"/> <add alias="downlevel" userAgent="Generic Downlevel"/> </clientTarget> ```

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig specialname rtspecialname instance void .ctor() cil managed

Docs.summary: Initializes a new instance of the class.

remarks.format: ## Remarks The ClientTargetCollection constructor is not intended to be used directly from your code. It is called by the ASP.NET configuration system. You obtain an instance of the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection> class by using the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetSection.ClientTargets%2A> property.

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void Add(class System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget clientTarget) cil managed

Docs.param: The to add to the collection.
Docs.summary: Adds the specified object to the collection.

remarks.format:
## Remarks Before adding a client target to the collection, you must create a <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget> object and initialize its <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget.Alias%2A> and <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget.UserAgent%2A> properties.
## Examples The following code example adds a <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget> object to the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection> collection.
For information about how to get the collection, see to the code example in the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection> class overview.
[!code-vb[System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget#5](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/70f32969-2262-44ca-b980-_1.vb)] [!code-cs[System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget#5](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/70f32969-2262-44ca-b980-_1.cs)]

Docs.summary: Returns an array of the keys for all the configuration elements contained in the collection.
Docs.value: The array of the keys for all of the objects contained in the .

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void Clear() cil managed

Docs.summary: Removes all the objects from the collection.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The result of updating the configuration file after calling the Clear method is dependent upon the <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationSaveMode> value chosen. To update the configuration file you use one of these two methods: <xref:System.Configuration.Configuration.Save%2A?displayProperty=fullName> or <xref:System.Configuration.Configuration.Save%2A?displayProperty=fullName>.
> [!NOTE] > Calling <xref:System.Configuration.Configuration.Save%2A?displayProperty=fullName> is equivalent to calling <xref:System.Configuration.Configuration.Save%2A> when the <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationSaveMode> value is modified.
If you use the <xref:System.Configuration.Configuration.Save%2A?displayProperty=fullName> method, the following conditions apply:
- If you pass the <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationSaveMode> or <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationSaveMode> parameter value, then a `clear` element is inserted into the `clientTarget` section of the configuration file at the current hierarchy level.
- If you pass the <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationSaveMode> parameter value, a series of `remove` elements are added to the `clientTarget` section of the configuration file at the current hierarchy level. This removes all references to the `add` elements defined in the parent configuration files at higher levels in the hierarchy. With the <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationSaveMode> enumeration value, one additional property on the collection affects what gets serialized to the configuration file. The property is <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationElementCollection.EmitClear%2A> and is `false` by default. One of the following conditions applies:
- When <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationElementCollection.EmitClear%2A> is set to `true`, a `clear` element is inserted into the `clientTarget` section of the configuration file at the current hierarchy level. This removes all references to the `add` elements defined in the parent configuration files at higher levels in the hierarchy.
- When <xref:System.Configuration.ConfigurationElementCollection.EmitClear%2A> is set to `false`, the `clear` element is removed from the `clientTarget` section of the configuration file at the current hierarchy level, if it exists.
The Clear method actually deletes the `add` elements defined in the `clientTarget` section of the configuration file at the current hierarchy level. It also removes all references to the `add` elements defined in the parent configuration files at higher levels in the hierarchy.
> [!NOTE] > The `add` elements are not deleted from the `clientTarget` section of the parent configuration files.
## Examples The following code example removes all the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget> objects from the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection> collection.
For information about how to get the collection, see the code example in the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection> class overview.
[!code-vb[System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget#6](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.web.configurati_28_1.vb)] [!code-cs[System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget#6](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.web.configurati_28_1.cs)]

MemberSignature.Value: .method public hidebysig instance void Remove(string name) cil managed

Docs.param: The alias of the to remove.
Docs.summary: Removes the object with the specified alias from the collection.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection.Remove%2A> method deletes the `add` element in the `clientTarget` section at the current hierarchy level and inserts a `remove` element. The `remove` element effectively removes the reference to the `add` element defined in the parent configuration files at higher levels in the hierarchy but does not delete it.
## Examples The following code example removes the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget> object from the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection> collection.
For information about how to get the collection, see the code example in the <xref:System.Web.Configuration.ClientTargetCollection> class overview.
[!code-vb[System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget#8](~/add/codesnippet/visualbasic/m-system.web.configurati_36_1.vb)] [!code-cs[System.Web.Configuration.ClientTarget#8](~/add/codesnippet/csharp/m-system.web.configurati_36_1.cs)]
